subject: Communication
title: Oratory in Ancient Democracies
description: A quick, practical guide to Oratory in Ancient Democracies.

hook.text: In ancient Athens, there were no lawyers. Every citizen had to speak for themselves in court.

buildup.text: The Assembly held votes on war, taxes, and law â€” and anyone could take the stage to argue.

discovery.text: Demosthenes overcame a speech impediment by practicing with pebbles in his mouth near crashing waves.

twist.text: Skilled orators held more power than generals. Words could redirect armies and topple leaders.

climax.text: Democracy was literally government by speech. Policy was decided not by rulers but by arguments.

punchline.text: The first democracy ran on rhetoric, not paperwork.

quiz.question: How did Demosthenes practice speaking clearly?
